user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_softirq_set:
```c
void metal_softirq_set(int irq)
{
	struct metal_irq_controller *cntr;

	cntr = &metal_softirq_cntr;

	if (irq < cntr->irq_base ||
	    irq >= (cntr->irq_base + cntr->irq_num)) {
		return;
	}

	irq -= cntr->irq_base;
	atomic_store(&metal_softirq_pending[irq], 1);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_softirq_set:
static METAL_IRQ_CONTROLLER_DECLARE(metal_softirq_cntr,
				    METAL_IRQ_ANY, METAL_SOFTIRQ_NUM,
				    NULL,
				    metal_softirq_set_enable, NULL,
				    metal_softirqs)
...
struct metal_irq_controller {
	int irq_base; /**< Start of IRQ number of the range managed by
		 	* the IRQ controller
		 	*/
	int irq_num; /**< Number of IRQs managed by the IRQ controller */
	void *arg; /**< Argument to pass to interrupt controller function */
	metal_irq_set_enable irq_set_enable; /**< function to set IRQ enable */
	metal_cntr_irq_register irq_register; /**< function to register IRQ
						* handler
						*/
	struct metal_list node; /**< list node */
	struct metal_irq *irqs; /**< Array of IRQs managed by the controller */
}
...

</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I inspected the provided target function metal_softirq_set and the related symbol definitions. There are no calls to memcmp or any other standard string-comparison functions, no operations on null-terminated strings, and no char*/string variables in the shown code. The macro METAL_IRQ_CONTROLLER_DECLARE and the struct definition as given do not contain memcmp either. Therefore there are no code fragments in the supplied code that could violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 (memcmp used to compare null-terminated strings). If other source files or macro expansions (not provided) contain memcmp calls, those would need to be inspected, but based on the supplied code there are no suspicious fragments to report.
